question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course is generally challenging. However, Prof. Rubinstein is one of the most famous polymer physics researcher and you will learn many useful concepts and methods for sure. Therefore, it is more than suitable for anyone who want to do research in fields related to polymer. My suggestion is to read the textbook before each lecture, then you can understand the materials better. You can also record any questions you have during reading the textbook and go to the lectures with these questions, as Prof. Rubinstein likes students to ask questions. For homework, going to office hours and recitations will be helpful.

I learned how to complete aldol reactions and how the products formed in this reaction can be used in diels alder reactions. I also learned the difference between acidic and basic hydrolysis and the separation of acetals. Lastly, I learned great study strategies like reaction mapping in order to understand the functions of a reaction.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Organic chemistry synthesis, specific arrow pushing mechanism and acid-base reactions, how organic chemistry relates to protein and amino acid synthesis

response_text: I developed a lot of skills, including how to study more effectively, how to manage my time better, and how to ask questions. I think I also learned how to understand the language of organic chemistry.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how to approach reaction questions more holistically instead of memorizing reactions. For instance, I gained a lot of insight on how to identify Lewis acids/bases, Bronsted acids/bases, and nucleophiles/electrophiles. I also have a lot more intuition when it comes to acid-base and intramolecular reactions. 
2. I developed an effective approach to synthesis questions, which is something I struggled a lot with in CHEM 202
3. I gained knowledge about how to approach reaction mechanisms and deduce the appropriate arrow pushing required

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Cox provides a lot of extra resources like past exams, practice questions, previous lectures, lecture recordings annotations and outlines, and more. He also holds office hours four times a week and is open to meet with students outside this time per request. He has "problem solving"o office hours in which he sends a problem set in advance that we complete during office hours. He also has "Q&A" office hours, which are more traditional as you can just come and ask whatever questions you may have. It's not common for professors to provide all of these resources to this extent so I am very grateful for that. He is clearly very excited about the course materials and loves chemistry very much. He has a passion for teaching.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: People say there's no memorization involved in orgo but that's not true. You need to remember the reagents for synthesis and roadmap problems where you predict the products of different reactions. I would make a quizlet of all the reactions/reagents and start memorizing these ASAP! Do the practice problems, specifically office hours and discussion. Many of the test/quiz questions came directly from office hours or were variants of these problems. The past exams are also good practice. Dr. Cox's textbook (OrganoMech) is also good for breaking down each topic and he also provides practice problems at the end of each chapter, which are of course helpful because he writes them himself. Dr. Cox emphasizes that the purpose of his exams are to evaluate our ability to recognize patterns so I guess you should try to be good at that. More specifically, looking for connections between the steps of reaction mechanisms, the different pathways you can use to produce a desired product, etc. Also pay attention in lecture -- Dr. Cox isn't a professor who tends to go off on tangents and ramble about random things. Everything he says is usually pretty important and if he hyperfixates on certain reactions or compounds, you will undoubtedly see it on an assessment.

response_text: Take it with Cox. He's the GOAT. Anyone else I will pray for you. The chem dept at Duke is largely fractured and inconsistent. Cox is always good don't risk your chem grade and understanding taking it with someone lesser.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a very hard course, as expected. And it requires a lot of discipline to stay on top of the content and consistently work problems, since there is no homework and discussion is optional/not graded. It's very easy to fall behind and try to cram everything in the few days before the exam, which does not work. Your grade is also 100% exam-based. So don't take this class alongside other challenging courses like physics. Also, come to class because lecture is not recorded and no lecture notes are posted. The one saving grace was Parise, who was an engaging/funny lecturer and generally made exams fair (if you had kept up with problems).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be ready to memorise a lot of the reactions and spend a lot of time doing readings out of class, practice, and learning. It is a very fast paced course and you need to stay on top of things to do average or even below average. Lab is also very time consuming, so be ready to manage your time well.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course requires a degree of self-sufficiency that most students do not have, particularly if this is not your only difficult course. Though many students have to take this for chem major/minor or pre-med requirements, be thoughtful about when you take it, and how much time you are able to dedicate on a weekly basis to studying this course outside of lecture. There is no way to do well in this course without many hours of individual work outside of lecture, as grades are based solely on exams, and exam questions assume you have done all of the textbook problems and readings in addition to lecture work.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Know that you will be spending a lot of extra hours in the week doing practice problems. Just showing up to lecture and discussion will not guarantee you a good grade in class. Most of the learning for me happened outside of lecture.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It’s a hard course, and you will need to spend a lot of time on it. Try to stay on top of the material as much as you can, and do practice every day (especially if taking in summer). Just try your best and don’t get discouraged. If you’re not good at applying concepts that you’ve just learned without having much time to process, avoid taking in summer.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is important especially during the summer session to stay on top of the lectures every day and not wait until the last minute to cram all of the information, especially since important topics are often taught a few days before the exam itself. Utilize the practice tests and discussion problem sets provided.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I strongly recommend against taking this course as a summer class. There is simply too much information to process in such a short duration of time even if you have the luxury of focusing solely on this course. You will be better off taking this class during the semester and doing your best to pair it with some less difficult classes. I was told that this course was more manageable during the summer, but I strongly disagree with that statement. No matter when you end up taking CHEM 202, I strongly encourage you to ask questions about things you don't understand. Information online will not always align with the preferences of your professor, so I generally think it is best to directly ask your professor about anything you have quesitons about. Dedicate time to studying the information you learn in class, and treat this course with the respect it deserves. It's known as a difficult class for a reason!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think this course helped me understand that the only real way to prepare for a test is through practice problems. That was something that was emphasized daily, and I tried to do as many practice problems as I could which was very helpful. I think that usually I am a reader and I will read the entire chapter before doing any practice, but I did not do that in this course and it actually worked out better for  me than in other classes. Since this class took place over the summer and was very rapid, I also think that it taught me a little bit of time management and daily scheduling. I started making a schedule right before I went to bed for the next day which became very helpful. With that, a big thing that was also mentioned daily was the fact that we needed to take breaks. I think that I learned in this class that when you take breaks and give yourself time off you really are more relaxed for when you start studying again and it is very refreshing to just let your self calm down and take an hour or even day for your own mental health.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought the learning environment of the class was wonderful as Canelas was very engaging and made sure that everyone was participating but also not worrying if they got the wrong answers or not. She would ask people questions throughout the class and give you points whether you got the question right or wrong, and then she would go through the question very slowly if most of the class was getting it wrong. She was very encouraging and always reassured the class that the material is hard, but if we just learned the mindset of solving the problems we would be able to do them. This class was on Zoom, but I think that she still did a great jon engaging everyone. She stayed after class for questions almost every day which was extremely helpful and she was always willing to go through more problems or answer any of your questions. I also thought that she was successful at trying to include interesting information that related to the material regarding medicine and daily life.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
In this course I've learned of numerous mechanisms in which reactions can occur. For example, Fischer esterification, Friedl Crafts, nucleophilic aromatic substition, Cleisen, and many others.
I learned how to recognize what method of mechanism the reactants underwent to yield a certain product. I also learned how to do stepwise mechanisms to lead me to a final product. In addition, I learned how to analyze the electrophilicity and nucleophilicity of a structure and what that means about the specific structure.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned topics about organic chemistry that built off of orgo 1. Specifically I learned about Diels-Aldar reactions, Electrophilic Aromatic Substitution, Acetals, Hemi-acetals, Carboxyllic Acids and their derivatives, etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have really learned the value of understanding patterns in problem-solving in this course. Especially within our focus on carbonyl mechanisms, I have found that rather than learning individual mechanisms, it is much more helpful to understand general patterns for application. I developed a similar mindset for analyzing trends such as acidity, electrophilic, etc. Three specific things I have learned within this course are carboxylic acid synthesis and derivatives, synthesis of amino acids, and electrophilic aromatic substitution reactions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course forces you to acquire highly technical problem solving and critical thinking skills. The content is incredibly difficult and the test/quiz questions are entirely application, so students are really pushed to develop qualitative analysis skills rather than memorization. It is impossible to memorize every single reaction in existence. You are forced to learn the processes of applying organic chemistry.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I learned when to remove myself from the learning environment because it was more hurtful than helpful. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class provided me with great insight on a variety of aspects including the structure and reactivity of various organic molecules including aromatic compounds, aldehydes, ketones, amines, carboxylic acids and much more. Something I really enjoyed was learning how to use basic organic molecules like benzene and synthesize complex compounds like amino acids and proteins. Near the end of the semester, we were able to relate the concepts we learned to biochemistry — which was extremely fascinating.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I am able to take a starting material and link it to a final product through a series of intermediate steps with appropriate molecules and solutions. Some of the reactions learned include the Robinson Annulation, Diels Alder, EAS, Amino Acid synthesis, and Aldol reactions.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I believe the course structure is designed to foster a profound comprehension of organic chemistry, seamlessly connecting various topics throughout the class. The instructor excels in conveying essential information during lectures. The teaching assistants and discussion sections provided an opportunity to apply lecture knowledge in a challenging yet rewarding manner. The teaching assistants also conducted "reaction ragers" before each exam, essentially holding a three-hour office hours session. In future iterations, I would retain the discussion sections, interactive homework assignments, and grading system. The hands-on instructional method, where the instructor guides through problems step-by-step without relying on PowerPoint presentations, proves beneficial in multiple ways.

response_text: Professor Cox had a lot of office hours, both Q and A and problem solving office hours. These were really helpful. The TAs are also really approachable and helpful. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Cox is a good lecturer. I think that sometimes the jargon goes a bit far considering that this class is intended for undergrads in their 2nd-3rd year, and not PhD students. Conceptually sometimes the instruction did not land, and led me to go above and beyond in searching for conceptual information that was often not accessible. TAs were accessible but sometimes were condescending.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The most significant help for me this year was office hours for problem-solving. What felt like an additional class every week to review the material helped me so much for this year. After class, I would understand the concepts, but in office hours with additional explanation from Dr. Cox solidified the material and answered all my questions. The TAs are very helpful. I felt they were easy to talk to and get help from. Dr. Cox also cares about his students so much. He is a very fast grader, yet he ensures that the students prioritize learning the material over getting a good grade. Some days, I felt like we went through challenging material a little too quickly, but with time, I eventually got the hang of everything. The discussion was constructive, with clarifying mechanisms and working through additional examples. I also love Aktiv because we get a few tries; it gives us time to reevaluate our answers and work through them to get the correct answers. I also loved the Wilkenson building. The long tables and multiple screens allowed us to collaborate, and the room layout made it easy to understand the class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is a more fun extension of Orgo 1. I have never had so much fun in a chemistry class. In this class, everything makes sense. The course is very cumulative and builds on itself. Sometimes it will challenge you, but once you figure it out, you feel like a mad scientist. It is much more straightforward than Orgo 1 and much easier to follow. You learn about molecules that smell bad like rotten eggs and molecules that smell great like vanilla just because they differ by one functional group. You will make giant webs of reactions and learn to synthesize products. You break giant molecules like carbohydrates into smaller funky-looking molecules. You get to make a chain of amino acids. Please take this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The best way to learn all the information in the course is to have everything structured in your head: group the reactions into categories (EAS, benzylic, phenyl halide, carbonyl reactions with strong nucleophiles, carbonyl reactions with weak nucleophiles, acyl chloride reactions, etc.) so that you can approach a problem with a specific idea of where to start. There's lots of information, but staying on top of it and mentally organizing/conceptualizing it is key!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take Orgo II with Dr. Cox! Dr. Cox does everything to help students. He hosts office hours, review sessions, and Q&A sessions. He has plenty of practice material available for students, and his lectures are detailed and very clear. He is fantastic.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Don't take this course unless you are sure about yourself and your mental health. You need to be confident because this course will take all your confidence away. I can confidently say it was one of the worst courses I have ever taken and would never recommend this amount of physical and mental damage/stress to anyone. Get an external tutor if you have the money for it because Dr. Cox is a poor professor. Take care of your physical health while taking this course because I was under so much stress that my physical well being started to deteriorate. I was seeing signs of major stress with my hair falling out, loss of appetite, fatigue, mental fogginess, lack of confidence, etc. Personally, I would not recommend this course to anyone. It's not worth how much of myself I had to give. I put so much effort into this class and got absolutely nothing out of it besides poor grades and a horrible mental and physical wellbeing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: "If you plan to take Chem 202... take it with Dr.Cox". I say this because Dr.Cox is truly the most caring, impactful, and brilliant professor I have ever had at Duke. His love for teaching and his care for students' learning and growth truly shows every single day. Dr.Cox is always willing to spend additional time to help enhance student learning. Over this past semester, there were several instances where I emailed Dr.Cox about scheduling meetings with him to discuss course material/study strategies and he would always make time to meet with me and help clarify any concepts. I absolutely enjoyed this course — and I am grateful to have had Dr.Cox as my professor. My passion for chemistry and particularly, organic chemistry has only increased after taking this course. I would give Dr.Cox my highest rating and truly believe he deserves a distinguished teaching award!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: As a student who enjoyed and did well in Organic Chemistry I, this course was extremely difficult and disheartening. The overall grade is made up of two midterms and one final, putting immense pressure on every exam. The material is interesting, but the exams are difficult and points are taken off for very small mistakes. There is little partial credit given, and the exams are typically long and hard to finish without rushing. Professor Widenhoefer does not like the textbook, so reading it is a waste of time and the only way to gain material is through the lectures.

response_text: It is difficult, but the content is interesting, and Dr. Widenhoefer is actually very good.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take with Parise. There is a reason the Parise section had 50+ people on the waitlist and Widenhoefer had extra space. When one of the exam averages was 64% and he said that was right where we should be, because a 70% average would be too high, that said everything. If a professor feels that a 64% average in a class mostly full of dedicated premeds is acceptable, they should rethink their teaching style. It's a shame most chem classes are taught so poorly at Duke. It's an incredible subject but the teaching style is really ruining most people's experience with chemistry, especially Orgo.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I feel much more confident with my understanding of the electronic basis of chemistry, such as the concept of pi orbital overlap and how that relates to resonance, the relationship between hybridization and geometry, the actual underlying (comparison of) comparisons being made when deciding what is more acidic, etc. 
2. I understand a lot more reactions, specifically with aromatic compounds, as well as with common functional groups like dienes, aldehydes/ketones, nitriles, anhydrides, esters, carbonyl groups in general, etc. 
3. I understand more about the theoretical discussion of reactions, like the molecular basis of kinetic vs. thermodynamic control, why the overall reaction rate is governed only by the rate-limiting step (and not an average of every step), how reactant stability relates to reactivity, why/what steps are bidirectional (in equilibrium) and how what steps go primarily in one direction (irreversible steps, RLS, etc.)

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instruction was good but the curve is KILLER.  The averages on tests are 65% and this curves to a B or B- depending on the semester.  To get an A, you need to be at least 1 Standard Deviation above the average.  However, on the exams, since a couple students get 100s while a couple score in the 20s and 30s, the SDs are absolutely absurd.  The standard deviation is generally ~20% or more.  This means that to get an A, you need to be at least 20% above the class average on all exams.  This course was unnecessarily difficult and is FAR more difficult than Cox or Parise or anyone else (all relatively easy).  DO NOT TAKE unless it's a last resort.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The lectures were useful and I liked that the slides and videos were published so I could review them later. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: My professor had these two discussion sheets. And this review applies only to these two specific sheets. One was the nuclear decay and another had to do redox (cells). These sheets are AMAZING. I can not stress how helpful they are. They walked me through the basics of concepts and allow places to workout the problems. As you go down the pages it becomes harder but at a good rate. I really do wish my professor had more sheets like this for every single discussion. Yes, we can ask our TA for clarifications, but when we finish the sheet on our time, the explanations and examples provided on the worksheet are so helpful. I would like to say that if these sheets were offered for every topic it would be a huge help. I think I learned so much from those sheets alone and could actually learn those concepts. Our professor would sometimes introduce themes through discussion before lecture, and doing through these specific worksheets is actually very helpful and impactful. I did not feel as overwhelmed as with other discussion sheets. Yes, individuals may argue that the beginning is very simple, but we still have to stress that not all students come from the same educational backgrounds. Yes we may have all taken 101 here at Duke, but that doesn't mean we are all on the same starting page. Not all the things learned in 101 can help you prepare for 201. Some students come from high schools in where AP chemistry was offered, and some students come from backgrounds in where little to no AP classes were offered. But what I really liked about these specific two worksheets, is that it just starts from the basics. No matter what your chemistry background is, it is important to start with the basics. And it is not that it even takes a lot of time to do, it just introduces you to the concepts in the beginning for you to make sure you understand. Yes, one can argue that the concepts can be explained in lecture, but that does not matter when you are currently in discussion. IN discussion, not in lecture. You can ask the TA for help, but when it turns out to be a simple concept that was not worth waiting for 10 minutes while the TA is answering other individuals questions, then it could have simply been explained in the worksheet. It is also stressful, since without these simple concept explanations and examples on the worksheets, how can discussion even be held with other students? Not everyone is on the same page in this situations, and one can argue that another student who understands a concept, can explain to another student instead of the TA (if TA is busy), but that should not be the student's job, especially in a limited 50 minute space. Which is why I really recommend to have those types of worksheets for every discussion, they are essential, and you can never go wrong with starting with the basics.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the focus on problem solving in class, as it helped make approaching the homework and textbook problems easier, and also helped me build my confidence so I would feel less stuck in tests. Similarly, while introducing new concepts in discussion felt frustrating at the time, it did help me become better exposed to and familiar with content, such as becoming far more comfortable finding edge lengths of atoms using their unit cell information. I also appreciated the unit plans with textbook problems, as I often used those as a starting point whilst studying so that I would feel more confident approaching practice tests.

response_text: Stay on top of the work! It is a lot of catch up on if you slip behind, especially if you try to cram everything in before the exam. However, if you do a little bit of chem each day, then not only will you remember the concepts better but you won't feel as stressed out the day before the exam.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

She provides old exams which are helpful for learning what material will be on the exam.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Dr. Canelas uses her bubbly personality to alleviate some of the more intense and difficult aspects of the course. Her humor kept me going through the material in the class that would've made me want to run away.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: To a student about to take the course in the future, I would recommend for them to definitely do it and especially with Professor Canelas. I really appreciated Professor Canelas' teaching style and authentic care for her students.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Dr Canales does not always cover everything you will need to know for homework, and you must work problems on your own to prepare for exams. The exams are difficult and while there is a curve its not super involved. The lecture is interesting and Canales is knowledgeable and good at breaking things down for you to understand. Also her demos are tons of fun.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that Professor Canelas is a very knowledgeable and funny teacher. However, I would also say that if you are a slower test taker like myself, this course will have exams that will have you rushed for time. Although the exams are fair, you definitely cannot rely on solely lectures to support you through this course. Sometimes the lectures can be a bit disorganized (ie: We spend the majority of class on a different topic/practice problem, leaving several slides we did not cover, which results in you having to go back after class and do the problems from the slides on your own). Additionally, I do like how she will tell stories which breaks up the lecture, making it a more engaging lecture, especially for a chemistry class. I did feel overall due to class timing issues we did not get to certain key topics and hope that that can be improved upon in the future.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Study the achieve, discussion questions and old practice exams!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Pretty interesting and engaging!!! Really recommend if you are interested in chemistry!!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say do practice problems, ask for help when needed, and go to class!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say to be prepared to spend a lot of time working through homework problems and to work on staying on top of homework/textbook problems. This makes preparing for exams a lot easier.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say to definitely read the textbook, at least skim it and write down relevant equations. I would also recommend doing many many practice problems. They aren't all super quick problems, especially when it comes to buffers and titrations, but they will make you MUCH quicker come exam day where exams are a bit tight on time.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you stay on top of the content, it is a manageable class. Dr. Canelas is a good professor to take it with.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Professor Canelas is a very engaging, funny professor with interesting stories and demonstrations to go along with her lectures, so I enjoyed going even at 8:30 in the morning. Inorganic chem II is a highly algebraic based class where a good understanding of stoichiometry and ICE charts is necessary for this class. There are Achieve assignments every week that do take a bit of time to complete and there is a textbook. The tests are hard in that there is a lot of content and not very much time, so learning to pace yourself is important.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Not too bad

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is challenging but very rewarding. It will help develop your critical thinking skills. Yes, this course will give you a deeper understanding of chemistry but it does so much more than that. The concepts taught and the skills developed in solving chemistry problems will help in all areas of life. Thank you, Dr. Canelas for a great course!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Make sure to study in advance and don't fall behind with course content.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Work on discussion sheets, and to manage time wisely. There is so many resources thrown at you, but chose the best ones that work for you. Also do not rely on past exams to study, they are not helpful when the exam structure is not the same as the practice exams. Also time yourself, because when taking these chem 210 exams there is little to no time to double check yourself. There is plenty of long problems, especially in multiple choice. Good luck!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would push them to take the course, especially with Dr Canelas! I think that Chem 210 sometimes has a reputation for being one of the "less important" Chemistry classes, but I feel that's not true. I not only became far more confident as a chemistry student during this class, but I also gained types of knowledge about chemistry that I am sure will continue to be useful throughout my time in the sciences at Duke. For instance, my knowledge of greenhouse gases gained could be applied to studying species and systems in biology. I also found Dr Canelas to be an extremely engaging lecturer who not only kept us entertained, but showed genuine care for our well-being, which made the class a pleasure to take!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Very good class. GO TO LECTURES

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There are different classes with the code "CHEM210" that are not actually the same course. The averages on exams in the Chem210 I took were less than 50%, and in other sections, the average on exams is an "A" grade. I feel I learned more in this class perhaps than students in other sections, but you might find that frustrating/feeling unfair.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is incredibly difficult. If you're not prepared to get 40s and 50s on exams, then you may need to consider finding another teacher. Lectures are going to feel like what you learn is anecdotal and the actual math you learn for the exams is going to be based in what you do in the homework and discussions. You will need to be studying THE ENTIRE WEEK leading up to any midterm (more, if you can) and even then, you won't get above a 70% on a test (60% if you're really lucky) and you're just going to have to learn be okay with that. The practice problems that you see outside of Zumdahl (the textbook) probably won't be the level of difficulty you see on the test and by that I mean the test will be much harder. I feel like he takes pride in knowing that he teaches a difficult subject, in the sense that he really should be teaching this at a graduate level but refuses to convey information in a more palatable way to undergraduates. He doesn't attempt to correct the fact that students are scoring so low on exams (failing, mainly). I've spoken to other students who have taken this class and said that this subject has been taught much more simply in the past by other teachers, in a way that students both understand the subject and score well on exams, so I know it is possible. I would even say I learned more from Dr. Martinez (the person who lead our discussions) than I ever did from Warren, and even then she (with her Phd) admitted she had difficulty explaining some of the course content that he was teaching. I urge you, if you value your GPA, take this class elsewhere or with another teacher.Additionally, I would just like to note that Warren joked about not being able to be fired via our comments, which may be true, but something about that statement being said so casually has some truth to it. He casually recognized that we have reason to say that he should be removed from teaching the class. This is not difficulty for the sake of deeper learning and thought, this is difficulty because cannot (or refuses to) stoop down to an undergraduate teaching level.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There are different classes with the code "CHEM210" that are not actually the same course. The averages on exams in the Chem210 I took were less than 50%, and in other sections, the average on exams is an "A" grade. I feel I learned more in this class perhaps than students in other sections, but you might find that frustrating/feeling unfair.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is incredibly difficult. If you're not prepared to get 40s and 50s on exams, then you may need to consider finding another teacher. Lectures are going to feel like what you learn is anecdotal and the actual math you learn for the exams is going to be based in what you do in the homework and discussions. You will need to be studying THE ENTIRE WEEK leading up to any midterm (more, if you can) and even then, you won't get above a 70% on a test (60% if you're really lucky) and you're just going to have to learn be okay with that. The practice problems that you see outside of Zumdahl (the textbook) probably won't be the level of difficulty you see on the test and by that I mean the test will be much harder. I feel like he takes pride in knowing that he teaches a difficult subject, in the sense that he really should be teaching this at a graduate level but refuses to convey information in a more palatable way to undergraduates. He doesn't attempt to correct the fact that students are scoring so low on exams (failing, mainly). I've spoken to other students who have taken this class and said that this subject has been taught much more simply in the past by other teachers, in a way that students both understand the subject and score well on exams, so I know it is possible. I would even say I learned more from Dr. Martinez (the person who lead our discussions) than I ever did from Warren, and even then she (with her Phd) admitted she had difficulty explaining some of the course content that he was teaching. I urge you, if you value your GPA, take this class elsewhere or with another teacher.Additionally, I would just like to note that Warren joked about not being able to be fired via our comments, which may be true, but something about that statement being said so casually has some truth to it. He casually recognized that we have reason to say that he should be removed from teaching the class. This is not difficulty for the sake of deeper learning and thought, this is difficulty because cannot (or refuses to) stoop down to an undergraduate teaching level.

response_text: I am deeply disappointed in the way this class ran. As a chemistry major, I was actually excited about taking this course as it discusses a lot of intriguing, intellectually stimulating, and important concepts for my academic future. The lecture ran as follows: A problem from the text book was presented, the concept was explained poorly with slides not made by the professor and that when he explained them it was clear that it was the first time he looked at them as the remarked "this doesn't really make sense to me, I think we should skip this, this is not a very good slide, etc.", and then we were "walked through the problem", which meant he just wrote on the board in silence for five minutes and continued to the next question. Nothing about this way of teaching was stimulating, and my success in the course came from reading the textbook and other independent PAID resources that I needed. These resources were not meant to aid my learning, as I have done for many course, they were my only source of learning since the class failed horrendously.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I do not recommend taking this class with Dr. Wiley. While exams were not difficult, I was very disappointed in the instruction I received in this course, and ended up learning most content from the textbook, the TAs, and the other professor's PowerPoints. Lectures consisted mostly of working problems from the textbook, which not only made it such that you only learned how to solve computational problems rather than learning the actual theory behind concepts, but were often riddled with errors. Despite the fact that all problems demonstrated in lecture were directly from the book (which has a key), Dr. Wiley often made conceptual and computational mistakes and had clearly not taken the time beforehand to look over his own notes, both of which actively hindered the learning environment. Slides that didn't come directly from Dr. Canelas were clearly made by ChatGPT, which speaks for itself. I STRONGLY recommend that the Chemistry department consider assigning another instructor to teach this course. Also, exams were very conceptually easy and always short, but very little partial credit was given, meaning that if you made one computational error in a part of one long question, your score automatically dropped 10%.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
DO NOT TAKE WITH WILEY. THIS IS NOT A DIFFICULT CHEM COURSE BUT HE MAKES IT HARD BECAUSE HE DOESN'T TEACH. 
Professor Wiley is, no exaggeration, easily the worst professor or teacher I have ever had in my entire life. His "teaching" style is that he reads practice problems (very obviously the first time he's seen them, showing no preparation for his own class) from a different professor's slides (he didn't even make his own lectures) and then proceeds to get them wrong. For the first time in my life a professor is not just bad at teaching to the point where I don't learn anything, but he actually makes everything more complicated and confusing because he keeps getting it wrong. And the entire class knew. I stopped going to lecture and actually learned better self-teaching. I'm not sure how Wiley ever got a job here but he is truly an embarrassment to the Chemistry Department and Duke as an institution. I am ashamed to go to a school where someone like him is called a Professor.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

Also this class is not that math heavy, you just need to know how to do algebra and take some basic derivatives/integrals.

response_text:

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a diverse toolkit for a quantitative and mathematical approach to the thermodynamics of gasses. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
Professor Moreno-Hernandez is clearly very passionate about thermodynamics and kinetics. It was clear to me that he prepared before classes and put effort into making the class a positive experience for us. He was good about asking for our feedback, offering office hours before exams, and communicating clearly when there were any changes to our usual meeting pattern. 
I appreciated that the lectures followed closely to the textbook so that if I didn't catch something in class, I could easily refer to the textbook. Especially in the later chapters, Professor Moreno-Hernandez started providing more examples of how the content is used in modern research. I found these examples both interesting and helpful for motivating our studies.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed when the professor would take the time to connect the concepts we were learning in class to his own research. I often found the mathematics to be isolated and separate from any real world chemistry I had seen or learned about, so it was great to be able to situate course content in real world applications.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

I appreciate being able to develop a more rigorous/mathematical understanding of basic chemical phenomena. Professor Moreno-Hernandez's enthusiasm for the material also made me more excited to learn this content.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was immensely challenging, but I wasn't necessarily particularly interested in some of the course content. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Physical chemistry is hard, period. However, taking this class will allow you to develop the fundamental conceptual and mathematical toolkit to think about chemical behavior for first principles. If you're interested in developing a more quantitative understanding of scientific phenomena, learning thermodynamics and kinetics is a must. It'll be hard, you'll spend a lot of time reading the Big Red textbook, and at times it might suck a little, but I still think the knowledge you gain is worth it. It's a tiny class, so definitely make friends with your peers and support each other. You'll be going through it together.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is immensely challenging, but the professor is extremely approachable, and it is not impossible to succeed by any means. You have to be willing to put in the time to understand the course. I would say that you should avoid this class unless you are very mathematically inclined and have a strong interest in both physics and chemistry. If not, take 301/302 instead of 310/311. If you are interested in these things, however, this course will be right for you.

response_text: The selection of topics for this course was really interesting and highly relevant to current research. I enjoyed that this course surveyed a lot of hot topics in chemical biology research. Overall, I felt like I got a lot out of the course relative to the effort I put in. Professor Derbyshire was also very accessible, approachable, and willing to provide feedback on our work. She was always very accommodating, allowing us to provide input on dates for exams and presentations based on what would work best for us. This helped to provide a minimally stressful learning experience with maximal gain.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course! Professor Derbyshire is fantastic and super accommodating and the topics are all highly interesting and relevant. Chem 517 is an excellent survey course that will help contextualize the real-world relevance of the things you learn about in standard lecture courses like organic chemistry or biochemistry. This course will push you to think about why you use specific techniques in research and how you can expand on current gaps in the literature to formulate a research project proposal. The workload is very reasonable, so you'll get a lot out of the course for what you put in. Discussions and much of the course are driven by the interests of your peers, so you'll learn about a lot of interesting science!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course is generally challenging. However, Prof. Rubinstein is one of the most famous polymer physics researcher and you will learn many useful concepts and methods for sure. Therefore, it is more than suitable for anyone who want to do research in fields related to polymer. My suggestion is to read the textbook before each lecture, then you can understand the materials better. You can also record any questions you have during reading the textbook and go to the lectures with these questions, as Prof. Rubinstein likes students to ask questions. For homework, going to office hours and recitations will be helpful.

response_text: I really enjoyed this course.  I found the lectures to be very informative.  I like that the slides were prepared and made available to the class. I particularly enjoyed the journal questions.  It was a great opportunity to dive into modern research relating to the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The overall learning environment of this course was both intellectually stimulating and supportive. The instructor explained difficult nanoscale concepts with clarity and patience, which made the material approachable even when it became quite technical. The lecture slides were well-organized, and the pacing allowed enough time to absorb complex ideas.One of the most effective components was the guided discussion of recent research papers. This not only helped connect fundamental theories to real-world applications but also improved my ability to critically read and analyze scientific literature. Another highlight was the inclusion of problem sets that focused on experimental methods such as AFM, STM, and nanoscale fabrication, which helped translate theory into practice.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: During class discussions, the current format has the students essentially talk about what they found in the readings (through answering questions from the 'discussion leader), and then we essentially present what we found with the class. This could be vague, in that we may have drastically different ideas due to not really understanding what we could/should be focusing on. A remedy can include the instructor acting like a 'guide,' where after students share what they found, the instructor can ask follow up questions or comments that point us to some specific direction. After students re-discuss among themselves, they may have a better idea of what to take away from the reading.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked everything about the structure of this class. The lecture on Monday of strict information and then 2 other days of working through problems with peers allowed me to essentially get a one-on-one tutor feel during class time which helped to learn material much faster. This class sets you up amazingly for success and dependent on how much work you put in, you can succeed. I actually had a good amount of chemistry experience in high school but felt unsure of how well I would do in a chem course in college, so I last minute decided to take 99D instead of 101 and am so glad I did. I probably could have done okay in 101 going straight in because I had chem experience in high school, and I still struggled to relearn basic concepts that all my teachers always assumed we knew but were never formally taught. It is so nice for Dr. Canelas and Anna to go fully in depth in explaining basic concepts that are never really taught in detail, at least in my experience, and they never make you feel stupid for asking "easy" to answer questions and in fact encourage more questions. I have talked to so many students in this class that had barely any chem experience in hs and are extremely grateful for having this opportunity to learn they didn't have in hs.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked everything about the structure of this class. The lecture on Monday of strict information and then 2 other days of working through problems with peers allowed me to essentially get a one-on-one tutor feel during class time which helped to learn material much faster. This class sets you up amazingly for success and dependent on how much work you put in, you can succeed. I actually had a good amount of chemistry experience in high school but felt unsure of how well I would do in a chem course in college, so I last minute decided to take 99D instead of 101 and am so glad I did. I probably could have done okay in 101 going straight in because I had chem experience in high school, and I still struggled to relearn basic concepts that all my teachers always assumed we knew but were never formally taught. It is so nice for Dr. Canelas and Anna to go fully in depth in explaining basic concepts that are never really taught in detail, at least in my experience, and they never make you feel stupid for asking "easy" to answer questions and in fact encourage more questions. I have talked to so many students in this class that had barely any chem experience in hs and are extremely grateful for having this opportunity to learn they didn't have in hs.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The overall learning environment of this course was both intellectually stimulating and supportive. The instructor explained difficult nanoscale concepts with clarity and patience, which made the material approachable even when it became quite technical. The lecture slides were well-organized, and the pacing allowed enough time to absorb complex ideas.One of the most effective components was the guided discussion of recent research papers. This not only helped connect fundamental theories to real-world applications but also improved my ability to critically read and analyze scientific literature. Another highlight was the inclusion of problem sets that focused on experimental methods such as AFM, STM, and nanoscale fabrication, which helped translate theory into practice.
